lessons.name: Present Simple Tense

contents.content: I/ you/ we/ they + bare infinitive
He/ she/ it/ James + Verb – s/ es

I/ you/ we/ they + do not + bare infinitive
Do not = don’t
contents.example: They don’t go to bed early.

contents.content:
He/ she/ it/ James + does not + bare infinitive
Does not = doesn’t
contents.example: James doesn’t go to bed early.

contents.content: Do + I/ you/ we/ they + bare infinitive?
contents.example: Do they go to bed early?

contents.content: Does + he/ she/ it/ James + bare infinitive?
contents.example: Does she go to bed early?

usages.usage: To describe habits, timetables, repeated actions or events
usages.example: She usually wakes up at 6 o’clock.
The Sun rises in the East
Don’t open that box. Throw it away.

usages.usage: To talk about something that is fixed in the future
usages.example: The bus leaves at 8 pm. Hurry up!

lessons.signalWords: Always, usually, often, sometimes, seldom, never, every day, every week, every month, every year, on Sundays, after school, before school

contents.title: Regular verbs are verbs formed by adding –ed to the end.
Unlikely, irregular verbs are verbs that do not form its simple past tense or past participle by adding –ed to the bare infinitive.

lessons.name: Modal verb
lessons.description: Modal verbs are used to talk about ability, possibility, obligation, prohibition, or to make requests or offers.

usages.example: I can play the piano very well.
